Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. *Find sources:* "Singapore Justice Party" – news **·** newspapers **·** books **·** scholar **·** JSTOR *(January 2021)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)* The **Singapore Justice Party** ([abbreviation](/wiki/Abbreviation): **SJP**) is a political party in Singapore. ## History The SJP was formed in August 1972 to represent the Indian community in Singapore. In 1975, SJP joined the United People Front (UPF), a political alliance with the [United National Front](/wiki/United_National_Front_(Singapore)), Singapore Chinese Party, [Singapore Malay National Organisation](/wiki/Singapore_Malay_National_Organisation) (PKMS) and members of the [Barisan Sosialis](/wiki/Barisan_Sosialis) (BS) and [United Front](/wiki/United_Front_(Singapore)) (UF). On 14 August 1976, SJP left the UPF. In November 1976, SJP joined the Joint Opposition Council, a political alliance with PKMS, BS and UF. SJP contested the [1980 general election](/wiki/1980_Singaporean_general_election) and fielded two candidates in [Ayer Rajah](/wiki/Ayer_Rajah_Constituency) and [West Coast Constituencies](/wiki/West_Coast_Constituency). From 1988 to 1992, the party was mostly active in [Marine Parade Group Representation Constituency](/wiki/Marine_Parade_Group_Representation_Constituency), where it contested in two general elections and one by-election. In the contested elections, it had lost to the [People's Action Party](/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party). It did not participate in the 1997 general election. In the run-up to the [2001 general election](/wiki/2001_Singapore_general_election), responding to [Chiam See Tong](/wiki/Chiam_See_Tong)'s call for a united front against the ruling [People's Action Party](/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party), the party joined with the [National Solidarity Party](/wiki/National_Solidarity_Party_(Singapore)), the [Singapore People's Party](/wiki/Singapore_People%27s_Party) and the [Singapore Malay National Organisation](/wiki/Singapore_Malay_National_Organisation) to form the [Singapore Democratic Alliance](/wiki/Singapore_Democratic_Alliance) (SDA). Although SJP failed to win any seats since it was formed, the SDA managed to win one seat at [Potong Pasir](/wiki/Potong_Pasir), with [Chiam See Tong](/wiki/Chiam_See_Tong) of the [Singapore People's Party](/wiki/Singapore_People%27s_Party) as Member of Parliament. In addition, [Steve Chia](/wiki/Steve_Chia) of the [National Solidarity Party](/wiki/National_Solidarity_Party_(Singapore)) was appointed as [Non-Constituency Member of Parliament](/wiki/Non-Constituency_Member_of_Parliament) (NCMP). In 1996, the chairman [Desmond Lim Bak Chuan](/wiki/Desmond_Lim) had left SJP to join the [Singapore People's Party](/wiki/Singapore_People%27s_Party) (SPP). From March 2006, Aminuddin bin Ami was appointed as the secretary-general of SJP. In March 2011, after SPP left the SDA, Lim left SPP and rejoined SJP.
